request_pathways.name: Mail to campus Medical Correspondence Unit
In-person at campus Medical Correspondence Unit

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patients submit records requests via a Verisma online portal with a dedicated 'Patient' link, or alternatively via MyChart or a paper Tripartite HIPAA authorization form selecting 'Patient Request' as the reason.

red_flags: Verisma portal requires two forms of photo ID for electronic submission
Date-of-service range mandatory — records will not be released without specific dates
Form states 'if you refuse to sign NYP will not release your records,' conflating third-party authorization requirements with patient access rights
bright_spots: 103 fillable PDF fields — fully interactive form designed for digital completion
Available in English, Spanish, and Chinese
Dedicated patient phone line 646-NYP-4ROI with stated business hours (M-F 8am-6pm)
Six delivery method options including patient portal at no cost
Comprehensive FAQ document with transparent MyChart record-type listings
Granular record selection with 16+ specific record-type checkboxes

findability.rationale: Level 4: Easy to find with basic navigation — medical records page reachable in 2 clicks from homepage, web searches surface it readily; minor friction from DAM-hosted PDF requiring URL extraction.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 4: Mostly digital — form-1 has 103 fillable fields for complete on-screen completion, and Verisma portal offers full online submission; one gap is that PDF submission still requires fax/mail, and portal demands two photo IDs.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized with minor clarity issues — logical section flow with bold headers, granular record-type options, but dense 2-page layout with some compound legalese in the authorization section.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: Patient can use the process but it wasn't designed for them — 'Patient Request' is one checkbox among seven on a generic HIPAA authorization form; no Right of Access language; portal offers separate patient link but underlying framework is third-party release.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: Minor ambiguities — fee language tracks HIPAA statutory standard, revocation rights stated, no notarization required; but mandatory date-of-service range, two-photo-ID portal requirement, and 'won't release if you don't sign' language create some unnecessary friction.

overall.summary: NYP delivers a technically strong, well-organized records request experience with excellent findability and multiple channels, but relies on a generic HIPAA authorization rather than a patient-access-specific pathway.
